content.text: (a) Determine the speed of the car at time \(=2.0 \mathrm{~s}\)
speed of the car =
(b) Calculate the distance travelled by the car between time \(=0\) and time \(=4.0 \mathrm{~s}\)
distance travelled =
(c) Calculate the deceleration of the car between time \(=0.5 \mathrm{~s}\) and time \(=4.0 \mathrm{~s}\)
deceleration =
1 A car travels at a speed of 20 m/s . The driver applies the brakes when he sees a red traffic light
Fig. 1.1 shows the speed-time graph for the car
(a) Show that the momentum of the space vehicle is approximately \(6.55 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)
(b) The capsule ejects the nose cone, as shown in Fig. 2.2
Determine the velocity \(v\) of the capsule after the nose cone is ejected. Give your answer to 3 significant figures
(c) A different space capsule returns to Earth
Fig. 2.3 shows this capsule just before it lands in the sea
The capsule travels at terminal velocity
The upward vertical force acting on the capsule is 120 kN
Calculate the mass of the capsule
mass of the capsule = \(\boxed {}\)
[Total: 6]
2 Fig. 2.1 shows a space vehicle which consists of a capsule and a nose cone
The space vehicle is moving at a velocity of 7800 m/s . The mass of the space vehicle is 840 kg
(a) The archer pulls back on the bow string, doing a total of 110 J of work. Her hand moves a distance of 0.45 m . The bow is bent and stores energy
Show that the average force applied by the archer in pulling the string back is approximately 240 N
(i) Calculate the initial speed \(v\) of the arrow
initial speed \(v =\)
(ii) Explain why the speed of the arrow as it hits the target is less than the value in (b)(i)
(b) The archer releases the bow string. All the energy in (a) is transferred to the arrow
The arrow moves off at an initial speed \(v\). The mass of the arrow is 0.030 kg
3 Fig. 3.1 shows an archer aiming an arrow at a target
(a) Explain how thermal energy is conducted through the copper base
(b) (i) Define, in words, specific heat capacity

(ii) A student heats a metal object to \(100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). The student places the metal object in an insulated cup containing water at \(22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). The final temperature of the water and the metal object is \(31^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
The specific heat capacity of water is \(4.2 \mathrm{~J} /(\mathrm{g}^{\circ} \mathrm{C})\)
The mass of the water in the insulated cup is 50 g
The mass of the metal object is 54 g
Calculate the specific heat capacity of the metal
4 Fig. 4.1 shows a pan with a copper base on a hotplate. The hotplate heats the pan and the water
(a) Define, in words, refractive index for a ray of light travelling from air to water
(b) On Fig. 5.1, draw the path of rays P and Q at the waterâ€“air boundary
(c) The angle of incidence for ray R is \(49^{\circ}\)
Calculate the refractive index of the water
refractive index =
(d) Explain why ray S is totally internally reflected at the water surface
5 Fig. 5.1 shows four rays of red light, P, Q, R and S, coming from a spotlight in a swimming pool
(a) Define the term ultrasound
(b) Describe what is meant by a longitudinal wave
(i) Describe how ultrasound is used to locate an object below the surface of the sea
You may draw a labelled diagram as part of your answer
(ii) State one other use of ultrasound
(c) Ultrasound is used to locate objects below the surface of the sea
6 Ultrasound is an example of a longitudinal wave
(a) Determine the value of the current measured by the ammeter
current = \(\mathrm{current} =\)
(b) Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) across the 6.0 \(\Omega\) resistor
p.d. = \(\mathrm{p.d.} =\)
(c) Show that the p.d. across the \(20 \Omega\) resistor is 9.0 V
(d) Calculate the resistance of resistor R
resistance = \(\mathrm{resistance} =\)
7 A student sets up the circuit shown in Fig. 7.1
8 (a) (i) State what is meant by an electric field
(ii) Fig. 8.1 shows a negative point charge
On Fig. 8.1, draw four field lines to show the pattern and the direction of the electric field due to the negative point charge
(b) The potential difference (p.d.) of a lightning strike is \(2.9 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~V}\). The energy transferred by the lightning strike is \(4.5 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~MJ}\)
Calculate the charge that flows
charge =
(c) The current in a lamp is 2.0 A . The lamp is switched on for a time of 120 s
Calculate the charge that flows
charge =
(i) There is an alternating current in the primary coil
Describe how an alternating current is produced in the secondary coil
(ii) A step-up transformer has a turns ratio of 1:20 . The voltage across the primary coil is 12 V
Calculate the voltage across the secondary coil
voltage across secondary coil =
9 (a) Fig. 9.1 shows a transformer
(b) The power lost in a cable is \(1.25 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~W}\). The resistance of the cable is \(0.050 \Omega\)
Calculate the current in the cable
[Total: 9]
(c) State two advantages of high-voltage transmission
10 (a) Define a light-year in words
(b) It takes light 490 s to travel from the Sun to the Earth
Calculate the distance from the Sun to the Earth
distance = \(\mathrm{km}\)
(c) Fig. 10.1 is a scatter graph showing how the speed of galaxies moving away from the Earth varies with their distances from the Earth
distance of galaxy from Earth/ \(10^{20} \text{km}\)
A scientist draws a best-fit line on the scatter graph
Use this best-fit line to determine a value for the Hubble constant
Hubble constant = \(\mathrm{km} / \mathrm{s}\)
(d) The speed of a receding galaxy can be estimated using redshift
Describe what is meant by redshift
11 (a) Define the half-life of a radioactive source
(i) Complete the nuclear equation for the decay
(ii) State the change that occurs in the nucleus during the decay
(b) A protactinium (Pa) nucleus decays into a uranium (U) nucleus by the emission of a beta particle ( \(\beta\) -particle)
(c) A different element decays by the emission of an alpha particle ( \(\alpha\) -particle)
Give two reasons why \(\alpha\) -particles are more strongly ionising than \(\beta\) -particles
